Caroline Smith and the Goodnight Sleeps new record is a bit like a nice cool glass of milk. Its wholesome, sweet, and generally colorless. Smith and Company originally rose to the top of the local music scene with pretty, infectiously youthful folk music and with Little Wind, they generally stick to that established formula. And while that doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t show a tremendous amount of artistic growth, fans of the bandsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ debut Backyard Tent Set should be more than satisfied with the ten new tracks. To a song they are pretty easy on the ears, and SmithÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s vocal talent is strong as ever.

Though the sound on Little Wind is on the poppy side, Smith utilizes somber inflection to give an overall tone of melancholy to her words. She sings about issues of family, friends, lovers etc. Ã¢â‚¬â€œ the usual suspects mainly, with tones of sweet solemnity. And though Smith is far from a bad lyricist, the emotional weight her words carry donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t always really get below the surface. Songs like Ã¢â‚¬Å“Tank TopÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ and Ã¢â‚¬Å“ScholarshipsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ deal with serious subject matter but the soundÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s poppy veneer and SmithÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s decidedly chaste thematic palette rob the tunes of their capacity to really stir the soul as much as they might. Smith seems unwilling to allow any ugliness to creep into her tunes or lyrics, making her words seem more superficial than the place they likely spring from (I do not doubt that Smith is confronting issues worthy of song).

Lyrics aside, SmithÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s songs seem to work best when she pares them down to the point where they largely rest on her vocals which are her strength. As is familial ballad Ã¢â‚¬Å“Eagles Nest.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Little Wind certainly doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t lack for talent (SmithÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s backing band the Goodnight Sleeps are also more than capable). SmithÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s voice, the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s instrumentation, even the lyrics all shine at points throughout the record. They might have shined brighter had they taken a few more chances (conversely the opposite might have also occurred) but as it stands, Little Wind is a strong album much along the same lines as Caroline SmithÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s previous efforts.
